docs.studentDialog:
I have some problems that I am gong to ask you to solve for me. Here are some things to help you count. You can use them or your fingers if you need them, but you don’t have to use them. Listen very carefully to each problem. If you need, I will repeat the problem for you. Okay, let’s get started.

Foya has 2 mangoes. Helen has 3 mangoes. How many mangoes do they have altogether?

[If the child answers correctly, say] That’s right. They have five mangoes altogether. Let’s do some more.  

[If the child answers incorrectly, say] They have five mangoes altogether. Watch me. [Use the counters and read the problem, demonstrating 2 counters for Foya and 3 counters for Helen.] When we count add them altogether, we get five mangoes. Let’s do some more. 

Now you will work out more questions that I will read to you. Remember some of these questions may be hard even for older children, so do your best. Remember, you can use these or your fingers to help you answer the questions.

[Point to the counters.] Okay, let’s get started.
docs.enumeratorHelp:
There is no stimulus sheet for this task.

Give the child paper on which to write and a pencil with which to write as well as a set of 20 counters.

Follow along on your screen and mark any item as either correct or incorrect. Your selected answer will turn yellow.

If the child makes 4 successive errors, the screen will "grey out" any remaining items. Say, “Thank you!”, discontinue this subtask, and go on to the next subtask.
If the child does not respond to an item after 5 SECONDS (and does not attempt to use counters, fingers, paper, or pencil), point to the next item and say, “Please go on.” Mark the skipped item as incorrect.
If the child is working but does not respond to an item after 1 MINUTE, mark item as wrong and move on.

The “[pause and check]” in each problem indicates that you should be certain that the child understands what you have said before continuing.  You may want to ask, “Do you understand?”

docs.studentDialog:
Here are some subtraction (take away) problems. Tell me the answers to as many as you can. If you don’t know an answer, move to the next problem.

Are you ready? … Start here, [point to first problem] go across, [sweep finger across first row] and tell me the answer to each problem.
docs.enumeratorHelp:
Student stimulus sheet EGMA F1-D2

Show the child the sheet in the student stimulus booklet as you read the instructions. 
Start the timer when the child attempts the first item. 
Follow along on your screen and mark any incorrect item by touching that item on the screen - it will turn blue. Mark self-corrections as correct by touching the item again - it will return to grey.

If the timer reaches 0 before the last item is read, the screen will flash red and the timer will stop. Tell the child to stop. Mark the final item attempted by touching it so that a bracket appears. Then press “Next.”
If the child reaches the last item before the screen flashes red, stop the timer as soon as the child reads the last letter. The bracket will automatically appear on the last word.  Verify your scores, and then press "Next".

If the child does not respond to an item after 5 SECONDS, point to the next item and say, “Please go on.” Mark the skipped item as incorrect.
docs.name: EGMA Task 4B. Subtraction

docs.prompt: 11. Does your teacher assign reading for you to do at home?

docs.studentDialog:
Here are some words. I would like you to read me as many words as you can (do not spell the words, but read them).
 
For example, this word is: “CAT”.
 
1. Now you try:  [point to the word “mat” and say] please read this word:
 
                            [If correct]: Good, this word is “mat.”
 
                           [If incorrect]: This word is “mat.”
 
2. Now try another one:  [point to the word “top”] please read this word:
 
                           [If correct]: Good, this word is “top.”
 
                          [If incorrect]: This word is “top.”
 
Do you understand what are you supposed to do? When I say “begin,” read the words as best as you can.  I will keep quiet and listen to you, unless you need help. Ready? Begin.
docs.enumeratorHelp:
Show the child the sheet of words in the student stimuli booklet. Read the instructions.

Start the timer when the child reads the first word.

Follow along on your screen and mark any incorrect words by touching that word on the screen until it turns blue. Mark self-corrections as correct by touching again until it returns to grey.

Stay quiet, except if the child hesitates for 3 seconds. Then point to the next word and say, “Please go on.” Mark the skipped word as incorrect.

If the timer runs out before the last item is read, the screen will flash red and the timer will stop. Tell the child to stop. Mark the final letter read by touching it so that a bracket appears, then press "Next".

If the child reaches the last item before the screen flashes red, stop the timer as soon as the child reads the last letter. Touch the last letter so the bracket appears, then press "Next".

Early stop rule: If the child does not provide a single correct response for the first 5 words, the screen will flash red and stop the timer. Say, “Thank you!”, discontinue this subtask, and go on to the next subtask.
docs.name: EGRA Task 3. Familiar Word Identification

docs.prompt: back ten tin
docs.name: pa_df_init_snd4

docs.studentDialog:
Here is a page full of letters of the ENGLISH alphabet. Please tell me the NAMES of as many letters of the alphabet as you can. Not their sounds, but their names.

For example, the name of this letter [point to the letter O] is “Oh”.

Let’s practice: Tell me the name of this letter [point to the letter V]:

[If the child responds correctly say]: Good, the name of this letter is “vee.”

[If the child does not respond correctly, say]: The name of this letter is “vee”.

Now try another one: Tell me the name of this letter [point to the letter L]:

[If the child responds correctly, say]: Good, the name of this letter is “ELL.”

[If the child does not respond correctly, say]: The name of this letter is “ELL.”

When I say “Begin,” start here [point to first letter] and go across the page [point]. Point to each letter and tell me the name of that letter in a loud voice. Read as quickly and carefully as you can. If you come to a letter you do not know, go on to the next letter. Put your finger on the first letter. Ready? Begin.
docs.enumeratorHelp:
Show the child the sheet of letters in the student stimuli booklet as you read the instructions.

Start the timer when the child reads the first letter.

Follow along on your screen and mark any incorrect letters by touching that letter on the screen until it turns blue. Mark self-corrections as correct by touching the screen again until it returns to grey.

Stay quiet, except if the child hesitates for 3 seconds. Then point to the next letter and say, “Please go on.” Mark the skipped letter as incorrect.

If the student provides the letter sound rather than the name, say: “Please tell me the NAME of the letter”. This prompt may be given only once during the exercise.

If the timer runs out before the last item is read, the screen will flash red and the timer will stop. Tell the child to stop. Mark the final letter read by touching it so that a bracket appears. Then press “Next.”

If the child reaches the last item before the screen flashes red, STOP the timer as soon as the child reads the last letter. The red bracket will automatically be placed on the last letter.  Verify that your scores are correct, then press “Next”.

Early stop rule: If the child does not provide a single correct response for the first 10 items, the screen will flash red and the timer will stop. Say, “Thank you!”, discontinue this subtask, and go on to the next subtask.
docs.name: EGRA Task 1. Letter Name Knowledge
docs.transitionComment: Good effort!  Let's go on to the next section.
